title: 111_hr5647
content: The Act is titled the "Responsible COBRA, Unemployment, and Poverty Extension Act" and includes provisions for extending unemployment insurance. The text chunk provides amendments to various sections related to unemployment benefits, changing dates from June 2, 2010, to September 30, 2010, and from November 6, 2010, to March 1, 2011. The Unemployment Compensation Extension Act of 2008 is amended to change the date from November 6, 2010, to March 1, 2011. Funding amendments are made to the Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2008. The effective date for these changes is retroactive to the Continuing Extension Act of 2010. SEC. 3. Extension and improvement of premium assistance for COBRA benefits. Extension of Eligibility Period for COBRA benefits under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 is amended to extend the deadline from May 31, 2010, to September 30, 2010. Additional rules are added for individuals experiencing qualifying events related to coverage in 2010. The amendment extends the eligibility period for COBRA benefits under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009. Rules similar to those in paragraphs (4)(A) and (7)(C) apply to continuation coverage for individuals experiencing qualifying events related to termination of employment after June 1, 2010. The effective date of the amendments is retroactive to the provisions of section 3001 of division B of the Act. The amendment extends the use of 2009 poverty guidelines until September 30, 2010. Additionally, $27 billion from unobligated funds under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 will be rescinded to offset increased spending resulting from the amendments. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will report these rescissions to congressional committees. SEC. 6. DETERMINATION OF BUDGETARY EFFECTS. The budgetary effects of this Act will be determined by the latest statement for compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010. The Act is designated as an emergency for pay-as-you-go principles in the House of Representatives and as an emergency requirement in the Senate. The Act, except for section 5, is an emergency requirement under the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010.
